headline: Is International Paper (IP) Offering An Opportunity After Recent Share Price Rebound
summary: If you are wondering whether International Paper is priced attractively right now, you are not alone. The stock has recently appeared on many value watchlists. The share price closed at US$41.84, with a 6.0% gain over the last 30 days, a 4.0% return year to date, a 25.7% decline over the past year, a 28.8% return over three years, and a 9.3% return over five years. Recent coverage around International Paper has focused on its positioning within the broader materials and packaging space and...

headline: AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL PARTNERS COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF INTERNATIONAL PAPER'S GLOBAL CELLULOSE FIBERS BUSINESS
summary: American Industrial Partners ("AIP"), a focused industrials investor, today announced that an affiliate of AIP has completed its acquisition of the Global Cellulose Fibers (GCF) business of International Paper (NYSE: IP; LSE: IPC). GCF now operates as an independent company.

raw.headline: AMERICAN INDUSTRIAL PARTNERS COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF INTERNATIONAL PAPER'S GLOBAL CELLULOSE FIBERS BUSINESS
raw.summary: American Industrial Partners ("AIP"), a focused industrials investor, today announced that an affiliate of AIP has completed its acquisition of the Global Cellulose Fibers (GCF) business of International Paper (NYSE: IP; LSE: IPC). GCF now operates as an independent company.

headline: International Paper Completes Sale of Global Cellulose Fibers Business to American Industrial Partners (AIP)
summary: International Paper (NYSE: IP; LSE: IPC), a global leader in sustainable packaging solutions, has completed the sale of its Global Cellulose Fibers (GCF) business to funds affiliated with American Industrial Partners (AIP). As part of the sale agreement, AIP acquired the GCF business for $1.5 billion including the issuance to International Paper of preferred stock with an aggregate initial liquidation preference of $190 million.

headline: 3 Cash-Burning Stocks We’re Skeptical Of
summary: Companies that burn cash at a rapid pace can run into serious trouble if they fail to secure funding. Without a clear path to profitability, these businesses risk dilution, mounting debt, or even bankruptcy.
